data.title: Unlocking the Wonders of Sitamarhi Temple
data.meta_description: Embark on a journey to the mystical Sitamarhi Temple in Bhadohi district, exploring its rich history, serene surroundings, and cultural significance.
data.text:
Exploring the Mystique of Sitamarhi Temple: Sita Samahit Sthal Bhadohi

Introduction:

Ladies and gentlemen, when we reflect on Sitamarhi, the sacred pilgrimage site associated with Maa Sita, our minds often gravitate towards the well-known location in Bihar. It is widely known that Maa Janaki was born in Punaura, Sitamarhi, Bihar. However, there is another Sitamarhi site that I wish to bring to your attention today. This particular site, also dedicated to Maa Sita, is situated in the Bhadohi district of Uttar Pradesh.

Yes, I am referring to Sitamarhi, the revered place where Sita was laid to rest.Unravel the enchanting tales of Sita Samahit Sthal in Bhadohi, a place steeped in history and spirituality. A revered tourist place in Bhadohi district. Join us to unravel the history, spirituality, and cultural richness of this sacred site.

Mythological, spiritual and religious importance of Sita Samahit Sthal

The Sita Samahit Sthal holds immense mythological, spiritual, and religious significance. It is a sacred place from the Treta Yuga, where Rishi Valmiki’s ashram is situated. This is the very location where the sons of Mother Sita, Luv and Kush, were born in the ashram of Rishi Valmiki. It is also the site where the sons of Lord Rama captured the horse released for the Ashwamedha Yagna.

In a remarkable display of valor, Luv and Kush defeated Lord Rama’s Chaturangini army, which included esteemed warriors like Laxman, Bharat, Shatrughan, Naal-Neel, and others. In a surprising turn of events, Mahabali Hanuman was sent by Lord Rama to retrieve the horse, only to be captured by Luv and Kush as well.

Lord Rama himself had to intervene and visit the Sita Samahit Sthal to uncover the identity of the formidable warriors who had bested his army. It was then revealed that Luv and Kush were none other than his own sons. The historical events that transpired at this sacred site continue to be revered and remembered for their profound significance in Hindu mythology.

Location of Sita Samahit Sthal and how to reach here

The Sita Samahit Sthal is a sacred pilgrimage site located in Baripur (Bankat) village, nestled on the banks of the revered Maa Ganga. Situated 11 km from the bustling Jangiganj market on National Highway (NH-2) between the historic cities of Varanasi and Prayagraj, this spiritual destination is easily accessible for devotees seeking solace and blessings. For those traveling from Varanasi, the Sita Samadhi Sthal is approximately 86 km away, while it is about 60 km from Prayagraj.

Map Location: https://maps.app.goo.gl/xrCLUyMYjoMiwcLa6

Jangiganj will be on your left side if you are coming from Varanasi, and on your right side if you are approaching from Prayagraj. Transportation options such as buses and taxis are readily available from both cities, ensuring a convenient journey for visitors.If you prefer to travel by air, the nearest airports are located in Varanasi and Prayagraj, from which you can easily reach the Sita Samadhi Sthal by bus or taxi.

For those arriving by train, the closest railway stations are Bhadohi and Mirzapur, providing a seamless connection to this sacred site. As you approach the temple, you will be greeted by the magnificent statue of Hanuman ji, a symbol of strength and devotion, marking the beginning of a spiritual experience at the Sita Samadhi Sthal.

Places to visit in Sitamarhi and things you can do here

The sacred abode of Jagat Janani Maa Bhagwati Sita is nestled on the banks of the purifying Patit Pavani, Paap Nashini Maa Ganga. The picturesque and enchanting environment surrounding this holy site is truly awe-inspiring, as it is embraced by the flowing waters of the Ganga and enveloped by lush forested areas. Across the Ganga lies a vast expanse of untouched forest land, adding to the serene ambiance of the location.

The temple itself is divided into two sections: the ancient temple dating back to the time of Rishi Valmiki ji, and the newer temple constructed a few decades ago. Upon ascending the stairs from the ghat after a cleansing dip in the Ganga, visitors are greeted by a grand bell that is rung by every devotee as a gesture of reverence to Mother Ganga.

The ancient temple of Rishi Valmiki ji stands proudly at the top, with a striking statue of Luv-Kush holding the horse from the Ashwamedha Yagna at its entrance, capturing a poignant moment from history.

Within the temple, statues of Mother Sita, Rishi Valmiki, Luv-Kush, and various other deities can be found. A majestic ancient Banyan tree graces the temple grounds, revered by locals as the Sita Vat Vriksha. Nearby, another ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva stands at the edge of the Ganga Ghat, surrounded by towering Vat and Peepal trees.

This sacred site is a haven for sages and saints who engage in continuous recitations of the Ramayana, devotional singing, and other spiritual practices. The atmosphere exudes a sense of divine power, tranquility, and positive energy, drawing devotees to participate in joyous celebrations such as dancing, singing Ram Bhajans, and chanting Ram-Jaap in the company of revered sages and saints.

Various centers of attraction in Sitamarhi New Temple

The newly constructed temple of Sita Samahit Sthal serves as both a religious site and a popular tourist destination. Upon entering through the main gate, visitors are greeted with a majestic depiction of Mother Sita in her royal form, reflecting her life in the grand palace of Ayodhya. However, as one descends to the lower level of the temple, they will encounter a statue of Mother Sita in the guise of a sanyasini, symbolizing her second exile to the forest and the hardships she endured while living as a recluse in sage Valmiki’s ashram.

It is at this lower level of the temple that Mother Sita fervently prayed to Jagat Janani Mother Bhagwati, seeking validation of her unwavering devotion to Lord Ram. Overwhelmed by the burden of proving her purity in a world that doubted her, Mother Sita beseeched Mother Bhagwati to appear and take her into her embrace. Moved by Mother Sita’s plea, the earth split open, and Mother Bhagwati manifested herself. Before returning to the earth, Mother Sita entrusted her sons Lav and Kush to Lord Ram, signifying her ultimate sacrifice.

Mother Sita’s origins can be traced back to Punaura village in Sitamarhi, Bihar, where she emerged from the earth during a time of famine in King Janak’s kingdom. Upon King Janak’s plough striking a metal object and unearthing a pot containing a beautiful girl, he adopted her as his daughter, naming her Sita due to her emergence from the earth. Just as Mother Sita emerged from the earth, she eventually returned to it, symbolizing the cyclical nature of life and the eternal bond between humanity and the earth.

Located within this temple is a unique form of Kush grass that is exclusive to this sacred site. Legend has it that Mother Sita herself used to comb her hair here, resulting in the grass growing in the likeness of her flowing locks. Even today, women come to worship this special grass, which can be found at the lower part of the temple entrance.

Surrounded by a forested area, the temple boasts a serene atmosphere. Visitors have the opportunity to partake in boating activities, which can be arranged in advance. As night falls, the temple is illuminated, enhancing its beauty and allure.

Within the temple complex, a magnificent statue of Lord Shiva stands atop a mountain, with an artificial waterfall cascading from his matted hair. Inside the mountain caves, devotees can find Mahadev’s Shivling. Nearby, an ancient statue of Mother Sita is nestled in the earth, while a statue of Swami Jitendrananda graces the entrance.

Outside the temple grounds, a new temple dedicated to Maa Durga has been erected. Adjacent to it stands a towering 108-foot statue of Hanuman, a beloved devotee of Lord Ram and Mother Janaki. The statue is designed to resemble a mountain with caves, housing statues of Lord Ram, Lakshman, Mother Janaki, and Hanuman.

The Hanuman temple complex exudes a sense of tranquility, providing a respite from the outside world. Lush green lawns and cozy huts under dense trees offer visitors a peaceful retreat. The massive Hanuman statue has become a popular attraction, serving as a focal point for selfies and admiration.

The statue of Hanuman Ji is the largest in Uttar Pradesh and is also recognized as one of the largest statues in the world. Standing tall and majestic, this impressive monument is a testament to the rich cultural heritage and artistic prowess of the region. Its grandeur and significance make it a must-see attraction for visitors from near and far.

Visitors to this site are captivated by the serene ambiance and spiritual energy, making it a must-visit destination for those seeking a connection with the divine.

Who built the new Sitamarhi temple ?

Swami Jitendrananda ji, a renowned monk, was instrumental in the construction of the new Sitamarhi temple. Born into a Brahmin family in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, Swami ji was a well-known lawyer before he embarked on his spiritual journey. Settling in Rishikesh, he pondered a question that had long troubled him: while religious texts and Puranas abound with references to Lord Ram, there seemed to be a glaring absence of any mention of the burial place of Mother Sita.

Drawing from the Valmiki Ramayana and Tulsi Geetawali, Swami ji was convinced that Mother Sita’s final resting place must be along the banks of the Ganga. Determined to uncover the truth, he embarked on a 900-kilometer journey on foot, scouring the ghats of the Ganga in search of the sacred site.

His quest led him to Sitamarhi, where he discovered an ancient temple dedicated to Sage Valmiki. Convinced that this forested region, also known as Baripur or Bankat, was where Mother Sita had been absorbed into the earth, Swami ji decided to make this his home. Embracing a life of austerity, he devoted himself to sadhana, subsisting on the offerings of the villagers and immersing himself in prayer.

One fateful night, Mother Sita appeared to Swami ji in a dream, revealing the exact location where she had been absorbed into the earth. Encouraged by this divine intervention, Swami ji set out to build the temple, guided by the signs and symbols mentioned in the scriptures. Through his unwavering faith and determination, he was able to pinpoint the precise spot where Mother Sita had merged with the earth, ensuring that her legacy would be honored for generations to come.Therefore, he initiated the construction of the temple by establishing the Satyanarayan Shriprakash Punj Trust in Delhi.

Accommodation Facility

If you are visiting from out of town and looking for accommodations, there is a well-appointed, air-conditioned hotel within the temple complex, as well as several guest houses nearby. The complex is known for its safety, with a police post located at the entrance. The local residents are known for their gentle demeanor and welcoming nature.

In addition to comfortable lodging options, visitors can enjoy a variety of delicious breakfast items, meals, and beverages. There are also numerous shops near the temple complex where visitors can purchase prasad and other items. Furthermore, there is a convenient shoe and slipper storage area available at the temple entrance for visitors’ use.

Embark on a journey to Sitamarhi and return with a treasure trove of cherished memories.

Sitamarhi holds a special place in the Shri Ramayana Circuit travel destination as part of the Dekho Apna Desh initiative by the Government of India and the Government of Uttar Pradesh. The religious, mythological, and spiritual significance of this holy place is evident through its inclusion in the Shri Ramayana Yatra, commencing on November 7, 2021, by IRCTC.

Personally, I have a deep-rooted connection to Sitamarhi, drawn to its mythological, religious, and spiritual essence. Each visit fills me with a renewed sense of spiritual energy and divinity. I encourage you to add this sacred destination to your travel itinerary and experience the same sense of tranquility and spiritual rejuvenation.

Conclusion:

Explore the surreal beauty and spiritual essence of Sita Samahit Sthal, where each corner holds tales of divinity and cultural richness, making it a must-visit destination for seekers of peace and enlightenment.Sita Samahit Sthal in Bhadohi unveils a tapestry of spirituality, cultural richness, and historical significance. Visitors are treated to a unique blend of serenity, vibrant cultural experiences, and spiritual sanctuaries, culminating in an immersive journey through time and devotion.

Dear travelers, I invite you to share your thoughts on this travelogue. Your feedback is valuable, and I look forward to hearing about your experiences. Feel free to leave a comment or send me a message. Safe travels!
